Since my current head is at (1,3), and the previous position was (1,2), I must check if it's allowed to move back to (1,2).

If the second segment of my body is at (1,2), then moving DOWN back to that is game over.

Therefore, moving DOWN is effectively moving backward into my own body.

Hence I cannot move DOWN.

From previous info, the other two options seem good:

- LEFT to (0,3): free.
- RIGHT to (2,3): free.

Of these, the apple at (3,2) is closest to (2,3) (distance 2 vs distance 4 from (0,3)).

So moving RIGHT to (2,3) seems optimal.

Moreover, from (2,3), I can move DOWN to (3,2) next turn and quickly eat the apple.

Therefore, I will move RIGHT this turn.

Next turn strategy:

- Move DOWN from (2,3) to (3,2) to grab the apple.
- Afterwards, plan to get other apples safely while avoiding collisions.

Move: RIGHT

1.rationale:
Let’s reassess from head (8,6):

Possible moves:
• UP → (8,7) is our own body (collision).  
• LEFT → (7,6), free, but doesn’t get us to the nearest apple.  
• DOWN → (8,5), free, heads toward (8,3) at distance 3.  
• RIGHT → (9,6), free, heads toward (9,8) at distance 3.

Two apples are equally close in Manhattan terms (8,3) and (9,8), but moving RIGHT immediately puts us on a direct path to (9,8) in three moves (RIGHT, UP, UP), avoids backtracking into ourselves, and keeps us clear of the enemy.

Next move: RIGHT

Strategy reminder for next turn: from (9,6) go UP twice to collect the apple at (9,8).
